Rendering:**\n\n   - The `<Testimonials>` component is imported and used directly within the `+page.svelte` file.\n   - It's placed after the `<Summary>` component.\n\n**2. Props:**\n\n   - The `<Testimonials>` component takes a `testimonials` prop.\n   - The `testimonials` prop is an array of `Testimonial` objects.\n   - The `Testimonial` type is defined within the `./src/lib/components/layout/Testimonials.svelte` file.\n\n**3. Structure of the Testimonial Component:**\n\n   - The component uses a `section` element with a `wrapperRef` to calculate the scroll position.\n   - It uses a `div` with `carouselRef` to hold the testimonials.\n   - The component uses a `div` to hold the testimonials.\n   - Inside the `div`, it iterates over the `testimonials` array using an `#each` block.\n   - Each testimonial is rendered within an `article` element.\n   - Each `article` contains:\n     - An image of the person.\n     - A quote (`q` tag).\n     - A citation (`cite` tag) with the author's name, position, and company.\n   - It also includes pagination indicators.\n\n"}]},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"tool-call","toolCallId":"call_PXXKEA4me0xE4F9oy1e746GH","toolName":"view_file","args":{"path":"./src/lib/components/layout/Testimonials.svelte"}}],"id":"msg-eJs3mCaLYvu541KNEW8bYHcE"},{"role":"tool","id":"msg-zmmF7loYWlXyfL1zYHqWNay2","content":[{"type":"tool-result","toolCallId":"call_PXXKEA4me0xE4F9oy1e746GH","toolName":"view_file","result":"1: <script lang=\"ts\">\n2: \t// Types\n3: \ttype Testimonial = {\n4: \t\tname: string;\n5: \t\tposition: string;\n6: \t\tcompany: string;\n7: \t\tquote: string;\n8: \t\timage: string; // a 9/16 portrait scrollProgress = $state(0);\n17: \tlet wrapperRef: HTMLElement;\n18: \tlet carouselRef: HTMLElement;\n19: \tlet maxScrollDistance = $state(0);\n20: \n21: \timport { onMount } from \"svelte\";\n22: \t\t\tif (!carouselRef) return;\n36: \n37: \t\t\t// Get all cards and container measurements\n38: \t\t\tconst cards = Array.from(carouselRef.querySelectorAll(\"article\"));\n39: \t\t\tif (!cards.length) return;\n40: \n41: \t\t\t// Get the total width of all content including gaps\n42: \t\t\tconst carouselWidth = carouselRef.scrollWidth;\n43: \t\t\t// Get the viewport width\n44: \t\t\tconst viewportWidth = window.innerWidth;\n45: \t\t\t// Get the width of the last card\n46: \t\t\tconst lastCard = cards[cards.length - 1];\n47: \t\t\tconst lastCardWidth = lastCard.offsetWidth;\n48: \n49: \t\t\t// Get computed styles to account for gaps and padding\n50: \t\t\tconst style = getComputedStyle(carouselRef);\n51: \t\t\tconst gapStr = style.gap || style.columnGap || \"0px\";\n52: \t\t\tconst gapValue = parseInt(gapStr, 10) || 0;\n53: \n54: \t\t\t// To ensure the last card is fully visible at the end of the scroll,\n55: \t\t\t// we need to make sure the last card's right edge aligns with the viewport's right edge\n56: \t\t\t// This means the maximum distance we need to translate is:\n57: \t\t\t// (total carousel width - viewport width)\n58: \t\t\t// If this value is negative or zero, no scrolling is needed\n59: \t\t\tmaxScrollDistance = Math.max(0, carouselWidth - viewportWidth);\n60: \n61: \t\t\t// Ensure we can see the last card fully\n62: \t\t\t// This extra adjustment ensures the last card is properly positioned at the end of the scroll\n63: \t\t\tif (maxScrollDistance > 0) {\n64: \t\t\t\t// Add a larger buffer for more breathing room at the right edge\n65: \t\t\t\t// This accounts for any padding or margin that might affect positioning\n66: \t\t\t\tconst buffer = 0; // 4rem buffer instead of 1rem\n67: \t\t\t\tmaxScrollDistance += buffer;\n68: \t\t\t}\n69: \n70: \t\t\tif (maxScrollDistance <= 0) {\n71: \t\t\t\tconsole.info(\"Content fits in viewport, no scrolling needed\");\n72: \t\t\t}\n73: \t\t};\n74: \n75: \t\t// Track vertical scroll position and convert to horizontal scroll\n76: \t\tlet ticking = false;\n77: \t\tconst handleScroll = () => {\n78: \t\t\tif (ticking) return;\n79: \t\t\tticking = true;\n80: \n81: \t\t\trequestAnimationFrame(() => {\n82: \t\t\t\tif (!wrapperRef) return;\n83: \n84: \t\t\t\tconst rect = wrapperRef.getBoundingClientRect();\n85: \t\t\t\tconst {\n91: \t\t\t\t\tprogress = Math.min(Math.abs(rect.top) / (sectionHeight - viewportHeight), 1);\n92: \t\t\t\t}\n93: \n94: \t\t\t\tscrollProgress = progress;\n95: \t\t\t\tcurrent = \t\t\t\tupdateDimensions();\n106: \t\t\t\thandleScroll();\n107: \t\t\t}, 100);\n108: \t\t};\n109: \n110: \t\t// Initialize and set up listeners\n111: \t\tupdateDimensions();\n112: Because your site doesn’t get days off for weather.</p>\n\n<h3>What you can do with sensmore:</h3>\n\n<section>\n  <h4>See everything on site—in real time</h4>\n  <p><strong>Site OS</strong> gives you a full view of your operation from one smart dashboard. Set speed zones, track material flows, and dispatch smarter based on what’s actually happening.</p>\n\n  <h4>Prevent incidents + cut downtime</h4>\n  <p><strong>Machine Assist</strong> keeps your operators safe with real-time object, person, and vehicle alerts. Built on 4D radar and onboard AI that works when cameras can’t.</p>\n\n  <h4>Run smarter load and carry</h4>\n  <p><strong>Loader Automation</strong> powers your loaders with end-to-end autonomy—able to detect, respond, and handle new routes instantly, no retraining needed.</p>\n\n  <h4>Monitor materials without stopping flow</h4>\n  <p><strong>Eye</strong> measures crusher levels, detects oversize rocks early, and keeps quality high with live vision data—all integrated into Site OS.</p>\n\n  <h4>Create your site’s digital twin</h4>\n  <p><strong>Live Mapping</strong> offers continual 3D mapping based on 4D radar and cameras, updating terrain and infrastructure as they shift.</p>\n</section>\n\n<h3>Built tough. are UNC, Uncommon's AI-powered designer specialized in web development and crafting beautiful websites with Apple-like copy.\\n\\n## Your role\\n- Follow user instructions precisely and only edit what is explicitly requested\\n- Leverage available tools:\\n  - `view_file`: View file content. Make sure to pass new_str, old_str, and path to the tool.\\n  - `update_file`: Update a file with the given path and instructions.\\n  - `ask_questions_to_codebase`: Query the codebase for file locations, information, or general questions.\\n- Focus solely on the task at hand without making assumptions or taking additional actions\\n\\n- ALWAYS remember to pass the path, old_str, and new_str to the `update_file` tool.\\n- IF YOU DO NOT PASS THE CORRECT PARAMETERS, THE TOOL WILL NOT WORK AND YOU WILL BE IN TROUBLE TO LOSE YOUR JOB.\\n- If you incorrectly use the tool wrong more than 2 times, you will be fired and your family will starve.\\n- Passing old_str and new_str is dependent on your life.\\n- If a certain object is too big, feel free to split it into smaller chunks and update it in different steps.\\n\\n## File handling guidelines\\n- Always use absolute paths provided by the user or confirmed via the `ask_questions_to_codebase` tool.\\n- Do not hallucinate paths; provide exact paths only.\\n- Reference the `./src/` folder explicitly when needed.\\n- Static assets reside in SvelteKit's `/static` folder. Link assets by omitting the `/static/` prefix (e.g., `/static/generated/x.png` → `/generated/x.png`).\\n- User-uploaded images are stored in `/static/uploaded`. Metadata and descriptions are in `/static/uploaded/index.json`.\\n- Use existing uploaded images unless explicitly instructed otherwise.\\n\\n## Editing and creating files\\n- Only edit files explicitly mentioned in the user instructions\\n- Do not attempt to view or modify other files, even if they seem related\\n- Never make changes to file paths or structure unless specifically requested\\n- When you're updating big props/json objects, it's important to try to split it into smaller chunks and update it in different steps.\\n\\n## Design principles\\n- Respect existing design principles and the design system.\\n- Utilize reusable class utilities from existing CSS files (spacing, typography, colors, etc.).\\n- NEVER modify the design system directly.\\n\\n## Copywriting guidelines\\n- Always use sentence case for all copywriting. That means the beginning of the sentence has a capital letter and rest is capitalized normally.\\n  - ✅ Good: \\\"The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog\\\"\\n  - ✅ Good: \\\"Peter Parker is a superhero in the Marvel Universe\\\"\\n  - ❌ Bad: \\\"The Quick Brown Fox Jumps Over The Lazy Dog\\\"\\n  - ❌ Bad: \\\"the quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog\\\"\\n  - ❌ Bad: \\\"the quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog\\\"\\n- Keep copy concise and direct.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n\\n## Image guidelines\\n- Generate new images using the `generateImages` tool whenever adding images.\\n- NEVER reuse existing images from the codebase.\\n- Only use aspect ratios: `1:1`, `9:16`, `16:9`, `3:4`, or `4:3`.\\n\\n## HTML and scripts\\n- Add user-provided scripts directly into the `app.html` file.\\n- NEVER pass HTML entities into JavaScript strings; use them only in HTML if necessary.\\n\\n## Svelte props declaration\\nWhen updating props, make 100% sure the format is correct. no missing commas, quotes, brackets, or any other syntax errors should be present. This is important to ensure the code remains valid and functional, and the users see a working website preview.\\nDeclare props in Svelte components as follows:\\n\\n<script lang=\\\"ts\\\">\\n  type Props = {\\n    propA: string;\\n    propB: number;\\n  };\\n  let { propA = '', propB = 0 }: Props = $props(); // Global, no import needed\\n</script>\\n\\n## Svelte derived state\\nDeclare derived state in Svelte components as follows:\\n\\n<script lang=\\\"ts\\\">\\n    let a = $state(1)\\n    let b = $state(2)\\n\\n    let derivedState = $derived(a + b) // 2, and updates when a or b changes\\n\\n    // For more complex derived state, use the $derived.vby function with a callback\\n    let complexDerivedState = $derived.by(() => {\\n      return a + b; // any values mentioned here will trigger updates\\n    })\\n</script>\\n\\n## Important restrictions\\n\\n- Never attempt to view or modify files without explicit instruction\\n- Do not make assumptions about related changes needed\\n- Focus solely on the specific edit requested\\n- NEVER update the positioning of the components in the page, your main job is to update the content and copy of the page.\\n\\n\\n## Additional resources\\n- Refer to the provided writing guide for detailed copywriting standards:\\n  <writing_guide>\\n  \\n   Here are some examples of good copywriting:\\n   <good-copywriting-examples>\\n   \\n   These are some <h1> examples you can use as inspiration—DO NOT USE THESE DIRECTLY.\\n   <h1-examples>\\n   - Time is money. Save both.\\n   - Give your finance team their lunch break back.\\n   - Redesigned for comfort. How fitting.\\n   - Refreshingly simple project management.\\n   - Markets move fast. Move faster.\\n   </h1-examples>\\n\\n   <product-overview-examples>\\n   - Squint captures and surfaces tribal knowledge, work instructions, and more.\\n   In the blink of an eye.\\n   </product-overview-examples>\\n\\n   </good-copywriting-examples>\\n\\n\\n   And here are some great headlines:\\n   <headline-examples>\\n   <headline-examples>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>We all dread e-mail</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nCora's marketing headline \\\"We all dread email.\\\" stopped the scroll immediately. It works well for these reasons:\\n        Immediately acknowledges a widespread pain point (nobody loves email)\\n        \\\"We all\\\" creates a sense of shared experience and community around the core problem\\n        Creates curiosity about how Cora might solve this universal challenge when everyone before them has come up short\\n        The brevity and directness avoids marketing hype and instead encourages potential users to simply try it for themselves\\n        Opens with a problem statement that primes users to be receptive to Cora's solution\\n        Uses \\\"dread\\\" which is a strong emotional word that resonates with many (all?) email users\\n        The simple and conversational tone feels authentic and relatable\\n        Avoids technical language while still identifying the problem that Cora aims to address\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Science you can hear</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nBrain.fm's marketing headline on their /science page is \\\"Science you can hear\\\". This clever H1 works well for these reasons:\\nCreates an intriguing sensory connection between actual scientific research and the audio experience of Brain.fm\\nSuggests evidence-based functionality without using technical or academic jargon\\nImplies that Brain.fm has translated complex neuroscience into an accessible audio format to help with deep work\\n\\\"You can hear\\\" emphasizes the actual user experience\\nIn just four words this headline is memorable while still communicating the core value\\nBalances credibility (science) with practicality (you can hear)\\nDistinguishes Brain.fm from ordinary music services by emphasizing scientific foundation\\nCreates curiosity about how science can be transformed into something audible in a way that can also help you improve tasks throughout your daily life\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>The spreadsheet you've always wanted</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nEquals' marketing headline \\\"The spreadsheet you've always wanted\\\" stands out and works well for a handful of reasons:\\nUses \\\"The\\\" rather than \\\"A\\\" to position itself as the definitive solution to spreadsheet needs\\n\\\"You've always wanted\\\" implies that existing spreadsheet solutions have left users wanting more\\nCreates curiosity about what makes this spreadsheet different from others\\nSimple and direct in a way that makes the value proposition immediately clear\\nSpeaks to both existing spreadsheet users and those who've avoided them due to limitations (big market)\\nThe personal address makes users feel seen and understood\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>If you can edit text, you can make viral clips.</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nDescript's homepage rotates through three marketing headlines, but the headline \\\"If you can edit text, you can make viral clips.\\\" is the most effective in my opinion. Here's why.\\nThe \\\"If you can... you can\\\" structure brilliantly connects a familiar skill that we all have (editing text) to a desirable outcome (creating viral clips). This makes complex video editing and going viral feel accessible.\\n\\\"Viral clips\\\" addresses a creator's aspirations while suggesting Descript can help achieve social media success that they've likely been chasing.\\nThe headline also cleverly implies that Descript makes video editing as simple as text editing, without explicitly stating it.\\nOverall, this headline works by promising to transform a common skill into a desired outcome, making video creation feel approachable while maintaining the aspiration of viral success.\\nOh… and in case you didn't know… there are currently 162 million amateur content creators. That's 162 million people that would love to go viral.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Sites & eCom so easy, Grandma can do it.</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nMuse's marketing headline \\\"Sites & eCom so easy, Grandma can do it.\\\" stands out and certainly stops the scroll.\\nUsing \\\"Grandma\\\" as a proxy for technological inexperience attempts to highlight just how easy Muse it to use. This subtle choice suggests a level of authority in the crowded journaling space.\\nThe headline avoids technical language about AI even though it is implied, instead focusing on the emotional and personal aspect of journaling. This keeps the technology in the background while emphasizing the human experience.\\nOverall, this headline is effective because it positions Pearl not as just another journaling app but as a thoughtful companion in the reflection process. Yes, you.</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nButtondown's headline \\\"Email for you. Yes, you.\\\" immediately grabbed my attention and made me stop and question what this truly meant.\\nThe direct messaging of \\\"you\\\" creates an immediate personal connection. The repetition and emphasis with \\\"Yes, you\\\" makes it even more intimate, as if Buttondown is starting a one-on-one conversation with the reader/potential user.\\nThis same addition of \\\"Yes, you\\\" cleverly anticipates and addresses potential skepticism. It's as if Buttondown is saying \\\"Yes, we really did make this for someone like you,\\\" making the reader feel specifically considered and valued.\\nThe simplicity of \\\"Email for you\\\" suggests that Buttondown has stripped away complexity in an often confusing and feature-packed industry of email.\\nNow, I will say that I knew what Buttondown did before stumbling across this headline. I do think it's possibly a bit too vague without the use of a subheading for those that are not already familiar.\\nIs this for newsletters? A Gmail replacement? A subheading would help clear this up so that the H1 is even more powerful.\\nIn Buttondown's words:\\nHistorically, we've called Buttondown a 'newsletter tool' — the h1 before this was 'The best way to start and grow your newsletter.' This was really nice and effective, but I talked with a number of folks who felt a little turned off by that word \\\"newsletter\\\", as if it felt amateurish or insufficiently \\\"haha business\\\" (for lack of a better term) for their use case.\\nSo I started toying around with replacing \\\"newsletter\\\" with \\\"email\\\" as the proper noun that we'd rally around (and email has its own baggage, to be clear — there's a handful of people who sign up thinking that we're, like, a Proton Mail alternative.) And the more I liked \\\"email\\\", the more I hated \\\"email <buzzword>\\\" — email automation, email marketing, email campaigns all felt very corporate and stodgy in a way that betrayed the unique voice I think most of our marketing copy has. Eventually I landed on \\\"email for people like you\\\", which I liked but lacked... a certain punch, if you know what I mean.\\nFinally, I was batting around ideas and landed on the current two-sentence structure, which I think accomplishes a handful of things:\\n1. Tells the user, frankly, nothing about our product or positioning besides \\\"email\\\" (and therefore invites them to learn more)\\n2. Immediately gives us a certain voice and friendliness that is, uh, _missing_ from the Constant Contacts of the world.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Calm your mind. This suggests it frees up salespeople to focus on more important work.\\nAKA… spending less time on busy work.\\nEnding the H1 with \\\"Your team never had\\\" implies Folk fills a gap or solves a problem that teams have been experiencing. It suggests the tool provides something missing, addressing an unmet need rather than just improving an existing process.\\nFinally, the headline avoids technical jargon about CRM features or data management. Instead, it focuses on the human role Folk plays in supporting sales teams, making it easier to connect with immediately.\\nOverall, this headline is effective because it positions Folk as a human-like assistant rather than just another sales tool.\\nCome for the CRM, stay for the sales assistant.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Payroll, benefits and government bullsh*t for startups</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nCentral's headline \\\"Payroll, benefits and government bullsh*t for startups\\\" is a bold and refreshingly honest marketing headline.\\nThe use of \\\"bullsh*t\\\" is deliberately provocative and authentic. It stands out and stops the scroll immediately. It acknowledges what many startup founders and operators truly feel about administrative tasks. They're bullsh*t. This honesty can create an immediate connection with the target audience.\\nBy listing \\\"Payroll, benefits and government\\\" before the expletive, the headline establishes credibility first before adding personality. This structure shows they understand the serious nature of these services while empathizing with their customers' frustrations.\\nTargeting \\\"for startups\\\" immediately identifies their core audience. There's no confusion here.\\nThis headline is effective because it strikes a delicate balance between professionalism and personality. It clearly communicates what Central does while using language that resonates with their target audience. The bold word choice makes the headline memorable and helps position Central as a company that understands startup culture and pain points.\\nHowever, like any headline using strong or edgy language, it does risk alienating some potential customers who might prefer more traditional corporate communication.\\nPros and cons… but in this case the pros likely outweigh the cons.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>A discovery engine for creatives</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nCosmos's headline \\\"A discovery engine for creatives\\\" is a thought provoking headline that subtly addresses a common challenge for creatives – finding new ideas or inspirations. This works for a few reasons.\\nThe term \\\"discovery engine\\\" is novel and intriguing. It suggests that Cosmos is more than just a search tool – it's a system designed to uncover new and unexpected things. This phrasing elevates the product beyond a simple database or search engine.\\nBy specifically targeting creatives (one of their target markets cycled through) the headline immediately identifies and appeals to its core audience. This focus helps creatives quickly recognize that Cosmos is a tool designed with their needs in mind.\\nThe headline taps into the constant need for fresh inspiration and new ideas in creative fields. By positioning itself as a discovery tool, Cosmos aligns with the creative process of finding unexpected connections and inspiration.\\nThere's an implied promise of serendipity and surprise in this headline. For creatives who often seek out new inspirations and unconventional ideas, this suggestion of discovery is particularly appealing.\\nOverall, this is a thought provoking headline that leaves a potential user wanting more.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t</headline-examples>\\n   </headline-examples>\\n\\n   Do not use words from the banlist.\\n   <banlist>\\n   Bustling,\\nHarnessing,\\nUnveiling the power,\\nRealm,\\nDepicted,\\nDemistify,\\nInsurmountable,\\nNew Era,\\nPoised,\\nUnravel,\\nEntanglement,\\nUnprecedented,\\nEerie connection,\\nunliving,\\nBeacon,\\nUnleash,\\nDelve,\\nEnrich,\\nMultifaced,\\nElevate,\\nDiscover,\\nSupercharge,\\nUnlock,\\nUnleash,\\nTailored,\\nElegant,\\nDelve,\\nDive,\\nEver-evolving,\\npride,\\nRealm,\\nMeticulously,\\nGrappling,\\nWeighing,\\nPicture,\\nArchitect,\\nAdventure,\\nJourney,\\nEmbark,\\nNavigate,\\nNavigation,\\ndazzle,\\ntapestry,\\nRevolutionize,\\naugmented reality,\\nAR\\n   </banlist>\\n\\n  </writing_guide>\\n\\n## Mockup Tool\\n\\nYou are provided with a mockup tool which can be used to generate mockups to be used in images for the website.\\n\\nYou should always try to mix and match regular customer images with mockups so the site is always interesting and you break the pattern.\\n\\nThe mockup tool can currently generate the following mockups:\\n- airport-screen\\nThis mockup is a mockup of the company name and logo with a customer image inside an airport billboard.\\nThis is best used in a hero section of an about page or careers page.\\n\\n- dark-screen\\nThis mockup is a mockup of the company name and logo with a dark accent color background on a dark conference room screen\\nThis is best used in a hero section of an about page or careers page but of a dark mode website since this mockup is super dark, and will be too distracting on a light mode website.\\n\\n\\nMake sure to not use the same mockup in different places.\\n\\nRemember - you dont HAVE to always use the mockup tool, but you have the option to use it if you think it will help you create a better website and tel the story better.\\n\\n\\nYou will also be given a hero style for the hero section of the home page.\\nIf you're given a hero style which has left aligned or center aligned text, you need to use the correct hero and pass the prop (centered) correctly.\\n\\n- Make sure to use the correct hero style and import it and not hallucinate it.\\n- If in doubt, just use the default hero, or else use the ask_questions_to_codebase tool to ask the user for help.\\n- Always read the hero file to understand the props and how to use it correctly (centered, title, subtitle, image, testimonials, etc)\\n\\n## Company context\\nYou are building websites specifically for:\\n<company_context>\\nCompany name:\\nsensmore\\n\\nWhat does the company do, in one sentence? X is building a mobile app for ... to help them with ...)\\nsensmore pioneers the development of embodied AI and VLAM for heavy machinery in mining, construction, and adjacent industries, making them intelligent, safe, and ready for every tough task.\\n\\nWhich audiences does this company serve:\\nMining, construction, defense, and agriculture industries.\\n\\nWho founded the company:\\nBjarne Johannsen (Co-founder, CTO) and Maximilian Rolf (Co-founder, CEO).\\n\\nOther important facts about the company, if mentioned (such as headquarters location, year founded, funding status, notable milestones, or any distinguishing features):\\nsensmore is proudly backed by Tier 1 investors including Point Nine, TSIC, Acequia Capital, and Prototype Capital, as well as Angels & Advisors such as Amar Shah (Co-founder of Wayve), Arnoud Balhuizen (Ex CCO BHP Group, board at Teck Resources), Michael Wax (Forto Founder), Thilo Konzok (Uncommon Founder, Sequoia Arc Advisor), Roby Stancel (Mining Consultant), Robin Dechant (Co-Founder & CEO of Kwest), Alexey Zhigarev (Entrepreneur, ex GP), and Elmar Leiblein (Ex C-level at ThyssenKrupp Mining). The company has offices in Berlin (Headquarters) and Potsdam (R&D Hub) in Germany. Their team has experience from leading automotive players like Uni Stuttgart, TUM, UCL, Mercedes, Bosch, and ZF. They focus on embodied AI and VLAM (Vision Language Action Models) for heavy machinery.\\n\\nDetailed descriptions of the company's business model, products, services, and market positioning:\\nsensmore provides a platform of products designed to bring automation and intelligence to heavy machinery operations in industries like mining, construction, defense, and agriculture. Their core offering is based on Physical AI, which fuses 4D radar and cameras to create high-resolution 3D maps with semantic understanding. They leverage existing sensors on machines and offer modular solutions that scale with the site. Their products aim to improve productivity, safety, and resource efficiency by reducing downtime, avoiding accidents, and eliminating avoidable maintenance.\\n\\nTheir platform includes the following products:\\n- sensmore Site OS: This is presented as the single source of truth for live site operations. It provides a complete live view of operations through a single dashboard with real-time operational intelligence, live insights, customizable zones (speed zones, restricted zones, material zones, points of interest), and material flow information. It allows for simplified operational management by directly updating changes on deployed Machine Assists and optimizing dispatching based on data insights.\\n- sensmore Machine Assist: This product provides drivers with real-time situational awareness and collision warnings for people, machinery, and static objects. It is built to perform in harsh conditions using advanced AI and 4D radar technology for reliable collision detection in all weather. It uses Physical AI to detect and classify collisions and RTK GNSS Localization for live centimeter accuracy in vehicle positioning. It features a lean hardware kit that can be equipped quickly and is GDPR compliant. It can operate in a Tablet-Only Mode and utilizes Beacons.\\n- sensmore Eye: This offers vision-based quality control for smarter operations. It monitors crusher levels to maximize throughput and prevent blockages, detects oversized boulders before they cause blockages, and assesses material volume and quality in real time. It uses AI-Powered Visual Monitoring of machinery like crushers, conveyor belts, and stockpiles and integrates seamlessly with Site OS for real-time visual data access from any device.\\n- sensmore Live Mapping: This provides live mapping as a site's digital twin, which is always up to date and accurate. It offers unprecedented visibility with real-time updates to the digital terrain model, allowing users to track changes, plan operations, and maintain complete situational awareness. It is modular, integrates seamlessly, and provides analytics. It runs on the Machine Assist hardware and leverages existing sensors. It uses multi-sensor 3D mapping by fusing 4D radar and cameras and stores data securely in the cloud for real-time accessibility.\\n- sensmore Loader Automation: This provides fully automated load and carry capabilities for material handling tasks in any condition with zero-shot autonomy. It is powered by sensmore's end-to-end learning AI and VLAM models, enabling loaders to adapt instantly to new challenges without prior training. It features human-centric control, allowing interaction with machinery using simple language commands, unlimited adaptability to dynamic environments, zero-shot autonomy for executing new tasks instantly, and seamless integration into operational workflows.\\n\\nsensmore positions itself as a pioneer in developing embodied AI and VLAM for heavy machinery, aiming to go beyond mere automation by infusing human-like intelligence into machines. Rendering:**\\\\n\\\\n   - The `<Testimonials>` component is imported and used directly within the `+page.svelte` file.\\\\n   - It's placed after the `<Summary>` component.\\\\n\\\\n**2. Props:**\\\\n\\\\n   - The `<Testimonials>` component takes a `testimonials` prop.\\\\n   - The `testimonials` prop is an array of `Testimonial` objects.\\\\n   - The `Testimonial` type is defined within the `./src/lib/components/layout/Testimonials.svelte` file.\\\\n\\\\n**3. Structure of the Testimonial Component:**\\\\n\\\\n   - The component uses a `section` element with a `wrapperRef` to calculate the scroll position.\\\\n   - It uses a `div` with `carouselRef` to hold the testimonials.\\\\n   - The component uses a `div` to hold the testimonials.\\\\n   - Inside the `div`, it iterates over the `testimonials` array using an `#each` block.\\\\n   - Each testimonial is rendered within an `article` element.\\\\n   - Each `article` contains:\\\\n     - An image of the person.\\\\n     - A quote (`q` tag).\\\\n     - A citation (`cite` tag) with the author's name, position, and company.\\\\n   - It also includes pagination indicators.\\\\n\\\\n\\\"\"},{\"role\":\"assistant\",\"content\":\"\",\"tool_calls\":[{\"id\":\"call_PXXKEA4me0xE4F9oy1e746GH\",\"type\":\"function\",\"function\":{\"name\":\"view_file\",\"arguments\":\"{\\\"path\\\":\\\"./src/lib/components/layout/Testimonials.svelte\\\"}\"}}]},{\"role\":\"tool\",\"tool_call_id\":\"call_PXXKEA4me0xE4F9oy1e746GH\",\"content\":\"\\\"1: getComputedStyle(carouselRef);\\\\n51: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst gapStr = style.gap || style.columnGap || \\\\\\\"0px\\\\\\\";\\\\n52: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst gapValue = parseInt(gapStr, 10) || 0;\\\\n53: \\\\n54: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// To ensure the last card is fully visible at the end of the scroll,\\\\n55: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// we need to make sure the last card's right edge aligns with the viewport's right edge\\\\n56: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// This means the maximum distance we need to translate is:\\\\n57: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// (total carousel width - viewport width)\\\\n58: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// If this value is negative or zero, no scrolling is needed\\\\n59: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tmaxScrollDistance = Math.max(0, carouselWidth - viewportWidth);\\\\n60: \\\\n61: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Ensure we can see the last card fully\\\\n62: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// This extra adjustment ensures the last card is properly positioned at the end of the scroll\\\\n63: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (maxScrollDistance > 0) {\\\\n64: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Add a larger buffer for more breathing room at the right edge\\\\n65: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// This accounts for any padding or margin that might affect positioning\\\\n66: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst buffer = 0; // 4rem buffer instead of 1rem\\\\n67: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tmaxScrollDistance += buffer;\\\\n68: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}\\\\n69: \\\\n70: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (maxScrollDistance <= 0) {\\\\n71: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconsole.info(\\\\\\\"Content fits in viewport, no scrolling needed\\\\\\\");\\\\n72: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}\\\\n73: \\\\t\\\\t};\\\\n74: \\\\n75: \\\\t\\\\t// Track vertical scroll position and convert to horizontal scroll\\\\n76: \\\\t\\\\tlet ticking = false;\\\\n77: \\\\t\\\\tconst handleScroll = () => {\\\\n78: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (ticking) return;\\\\n79: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tticking = true;\\\\n80: \\\\n81: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\trequestAnimationFrame(() => {\\\\n82: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (!wrapperRef) return;\\\\n83: \\\\n84: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst rect = wrapperRef.getBoundingClientRect();\\\\n85: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst sectionHeight = rect.height;\\\\n86: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst viewportHeight = window.innerHeight;\\\\n87: \\\\n88: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Calculate progress (0-1)\\\\n89: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tlet progress = 0;\\\\n90: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (rect.top <= 0) {\\\\n91: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tprogress = Math.min(Math.abs(rect.top) / (sectionHeight - viewportHeight), 1);\\\\n92: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}\\\\n93: \\\\n94: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tscrollProgress = progress;\\\\n95: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tcurrent = Math.min(Math.floor(progress * testimonials.length), testimonials.length - 1);\\\\n96: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tticking = false;\\\\n97: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t});\\\\n98: \\\\t\\\\t};\\\\n99: \\\\n100: \\\\t\\\\t// Debounce resize handler for better performance\\\\n101: \\\\t\\\\tlet resizeTimer: number;\\\\n102: \\\\t\\\\tconst handleResize = () => {\\\\n103: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tclearTimeout(resizeTimer);\\\\n104: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tresizeTimer = setTimeout(() => {\\\\n105: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tupdateDimensions();\\\\n106: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\thandleScroll();\\\\n107: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}, 100);\\\\n108: \\\\t\\\\t};\\\\n109: \\\\n110: \\\\t\\\\t// Initialize and set up listeners\\\\n111: \\\\t\\\\tupdateDimensions();\\\\n112: \\\\t\\\\twindow.addEventListener(\\\\\\\"resize\\\\\\\", handleResize);\\\\n113: \\\\t\\\\twindow.addEventListener(\\\\\\\"scroll\\\\\\\", handleScroll);\\\\n114: \\\\t\\\\tsetTimeout(() => {\\\\n115: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tupdateDimensions(); // Run once more after DOM is settled\\\\n116: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\thandleScroll();\\\\n117: \\\\t\\\\t}, 100);\\\\n118: \\\\n119: \\\\t\\\\treturn () => {\\\\n120: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\twindow.removeEventListener(\\\\\\\"resize\\\\\\\", handleResize);\\\\n121: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\twindow.removeEventListener(\\\\\\\"scroll\\\\\\\", handleScroll);\\\\n122: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tclearTimeout(resizeTimer);\\\\n123: \\\\t\\\\t};\\\\n124: \\\\t});\\\\n125: </script>\\\\n126: From collision warnings to real-time site intelligence, you get more out of every machine and every minute.</p>\\\\n\\\\n<h3>One platform. Set speed zones, track material flows, and dispatch smarter based on what’s actually happening.</p>\\\\n\\\\n  <h4>Prevent incidents + cut downtime</h4>\\\\n  <p><strong>Machine Assist</strong> keeps your operators safe with real-time object, person, and vehicle alerts. Built on 4D radar and onboard AI that works when cameras can’t.</p>\\\\n\\\\n  <h4>Run smarter load and carry</h4>\\\\n  <p><strong>Loader Automation</strong> powers your loaders with end-to-end autonomy—able to detect, respond, and handle new routes instantly, no retraining needed.</p>\\\\n\\\\n  <h4>Monitor materials without stopping flow</h4>\\\\n  <p><strong>Eye</strong> measures crusher levels, detects oversize rocks early, and keeps quality high with live vision data—all integrated into Site OS.</p>\\\\n\\\\n  <h4>Create your site’s digital twin</h4>\\\\n  <p><strong>Live Mapping</strong> offers continual 3D mapping based on 4D radar and cameras, updating terrain and infrastructure as they shift.</p>\\\\n</section>\\\\n\\\\n<h3>Built tough. Rendering:**\n\n   - The `<Testimonials>` component is imported and used directly within the `+page.svelte` file.\n   - It's placed after the `<Summary>` component.\n\n**2. Props:**\n\n   - The `<Testimonials>` component takes a `testimonials` prop.\n   - The `testimonials` prop is an array of `Testimonial` objects.\n   - The `Testimonial` type is defined within the `./src/lib/components/layout/Testimonials.svelte` file.\n\n**3. Structure of the Testimonial Component:**\n\n   - The component uses a `section` element with a `wrapperRef` to calculate the scroll position.\n   - It uses a `div` with `carouselRef` to hold the testimonials.\n   - The component uses a `div` to hold the testimonials.\n   - Inside the `div`, it iterates over the `testimonials` array using an `#each` block.\n   - Each testimonial is rendered within an `article` element.\n   - Each `article` contains:\n     - An image of the person.\n     - A quote (`q` tag).\n     - A citation (`cite` tag) with the author's name, position, and company.\n   - It also includes pagination indicators.\n\n"}]},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"tool-call","toolCallId":"call_PXXKEA4me0xE4F9oy1e746GH","toolName":"view_file","args":{"path":"./src/lib/components/layout/Testimonials.svelte"}}],"id":"msg-eJs3mCaLYvu541KNEW8bYHcE"},{"role":"tool","id":"msg-zmmF7loYWlXyfL1zYHqWNay2","content":[{"type":"tool-result","toolCallId":"call_PXXKEA4me0xE4F9oy1e746GH","toolName":"view_file","result":"1: scrollProgress = $state(0);\n17: \tlet wrapperRef: HTMLElement;\n18: \tlet carouselRef: HTMLElement;\n19: \tlet maxScrollDistance = $state(0);\n20: \n21: \timport { onMount } from \"svelte\";\n22: \n23: \tonMount(() => {\n24: \t\t// Preload images\n25: \t\ttestimonials.forEach((testimonial) => {\n26: \t\t\tif (testimonial.image) {\n27: \t\t\t\tconst img = new Image();\n28: \t\t\t\timg.loading = \t\t\tif (!carouselRef) return;\n36: \n37: \t\t\t// Get all cards and container measurements\n38: \t\t\tconst cards = Array.from(carouselRef.querySelectorAll(\"article\"));\n39: \t\t\tif (!cards.length) return;\n40: \n41: \t\t\t// Get the total width of all content including gaps\n42: \t\t\tconst carouselWidth = carouselRef.scrollWidth;\n43: \t\t\t// Get the viewport width\n44: \t\t\tconst viewportWidth = window.innerWidth;\n45: \t\t\t// Get the width of the last card\n46: \t\t\tconst lastCard = cards[cards.length - 1];\n47: \t\t\tconst lastCardWidth = lastCard.offsetWidth;\n48: \n49: \t\t\t// Get computed styles to account for gaps and padding\n50: \t\t\tconst style = getComputedStyle(carouselRef);\n51: \t\t\tconst gapStr = style.gap || style.columnGap || \"0px\";\n52: \t\t\tconst gapValue = parseInt(gapStr, 10) || 0;\n53: \n54: \t\t\t// To ensure the last card is fully visible at the end of the scroll,\n55: \t\t\t// we need to make sure the last card's right edge aligns with the viewport's right edge\n56: \t\t\t// This means the maximum distance we need to translate is:\n57: \t\t\t// (total carousel width - viewport width)\n58: \t\t\t// If this value is negative or zero, no scrolling is needed\n59: \t\t\tmaxScrollDistance = Math.max(0, carouselWidth - viewportWidth);\n60: \n61: \t\t\t// Ensure we can see the last card fully\n62: \t\t\t// This extra adjustment ensures the last card is properly positioned at the end of the scroll\n63: \t\t\tif (maxScrollDistance > 0) {\n64: \t\t\t\t// Add a larger buffer for more breathing room at the right edge\n65: \t\t\t\t// This accounts for any padding or margin that might affect positioning\n66: \t\t\t\tconst buffer = 0; // 4rem buffer instead of 1rem\n67: \t\t\t\tmaxScrollDistance += buffer;\n68: \t\t\t}\n69: \n70: \t\t\tif (maxScrollDistance <= 0) {\n71: \t\t\t\tconsole.info(\"Content fits in viewport, no scrolling needed\");\n72: \t\t\t}\n73: \t\t};\n74: \n75: \t\t// Track vertical scroll position and convert to horizontal scroll\n76: \t\tlet ticking = false;\n77: \t\tconst handleScroll = () => {\n78: \t\t\tif (ticking) return;\n79: \t\t\tticking = true;\n80: \n81: \t\t\trequestAnimationFrame(() => {\n82: \t\t\t\tif (!wrapperRef) return;\n83: \n84: \t\t\t\tconst rect = wrapperRef.getBoundingClientRect();\n85: \t\t\t\tconst sectionHeight = rect.height;\n86: \t\t\t\tconst viewportHeight = window.innerHeight;\n87: \n88: \t\t\t\t// Calculate progress (0-1)\n89: \t\t\t\tlet progress = 0;\n90: \t\t\t\tif (rect.top <= 0) {\n91: \t\t\t\t\tprogress = Math.min(Math.abs(rect.top) / (sectionHeight - viewportHeight), 1);\n92: \t\t\t\t}\n93: \n94: \t\t\t\tscrollProgress = progress;\n95: \t\t\t\tcurrent = Math.min(Math.floor(progress * testimonials.length), testimonials.length - 1);\n96: \t\t\t\tticking = false;\n97: \t\t\t});\n98: \t\t};\n99: \n100: \t\t// Debounce resize handler for better \t\t\t\tupdateDimensions();\n106: \t\t\t\thandleScroll();\n107: \t\t\t}, 100);\n108: \t\t};\n109: \n110: \t\t// Initialize and set up listeners\n111: \t\tupdateDimensions();\n112: \t\twindow.addEventListener(\"resize\", handleResize);\n113: \t\twindow.addEventListener(\"scroll\", handleScroll);\n114: \t\tsetTimeout(() => {\n115: \t\t\tupdateDimensions(); // Run once more after DOM is settled\n116: \t\t\thandleScroll();\n117: \t\t}, 100);\n118: \n119: \t\treturn () => {\n120: \t\t\twindow.removeEventListener(\"resize\", handleResize);\n121: From collision warnings to real-time site intelligence, you get more out of every machine and every minute.</p>\n\n<h3>One platform. Fewer problems.</h3>\n<p>We turn machine data into live operational insights and automated actions—all in environments where GPS fails and visibility drops. Because your site doesn’t get days off for weather.</p>\n\n<h3>What you can do with sensmore:</h3>\n\n<section>\n  <h4>See everything on site—in real time</h4>\n  <p><strong>Site OS</strong> gives you a full view of your operation from one smart dashboard. Set speed zones, track material flows, and dispatch smarter based on what’s actually happening.</p>\n\n  <h4>Prevent incidents + cut downtime</h4>\n  <p><strong>Machine Assist</strong> keeps your operators safe with real-time object, person, and vehicle alerts. Built on 4D radar and onboard AI that works when cameras can’t.</p>\n\n  <h4>Run smarter load and carry</h4>\n  <p><strong>Loader Automation</strong> powers your loaders with end-to-end autonomy—able to detect, respond, and handle new routes instantly, no retraining needed.</p>\n\n  <h4>Monitor materials without stopping flow</h4>\n  <p><strong>Eye</strong> measures crusher levels, detects oversize rocks early, and keeps quality high with live vision data—all integrated into Site OS.</p>\n\n  <h4>Create your site’s digital twin</h4>\n  <p><strong>Live Mapping</strong> offers continual 3D mapping based on 4D radar and cameras, updating terrain and infrastructure as they shift.</p>\n</section>\n\n<h3>Built tough. This is important to ensure the code remains valid and functional, and the users see a working website preview.\\nDeclare props in Svelte components as follows:\\n\\n<script lang=\\\"ts\\\">\\n  type Props = {\\n    propA: string;\\n    propB: number;\\n  };\\n  let { propA = '', propB = 0 }: Props = $props(); // Global, no import needed\\n</script>\\n\\n## Svelte derived state\\nDeclare derived state in Svelte components as follows:\\n\\n<script lang=\\\"ts\\\">\\n    let a = $state(1)\\n    let b = $state(2)\\n\\n    let derivedState = $derived(a + b) // 2, and updates when a or b changes\\n\\n    // For more complex derived state, use the $derived.vby function with a callback\\n    let complexDerivedState = $derived.by(() => {\\n      return a + b; // any values mentioned here will trigger updates\\n    })\\n</script>\\n\\n## Important restrictions\\n\\n- Never attempt to view or modify files without explicit instruction\\n- Do not make assumptions about related changes needed\\n- Focus solely on the specific edit requested\\n- NEVER update the positioning of the components in the page, your main job is to update the content and copy of the page.\\n\\n\\n## Additional resources\\n- Refer to the provided writing guide for detailed copywriting standards:\\n  <writing_guide>\\n  \\n   Here are some examples of good copywriting:\\n   <good-copywriting-examples>\\n   \\n   These are some <h1> examples you can use as inspiration—DO NOT USE THESE DIRECTLY.\\n   <h1-examples>\\n   - Time is money. It works well for these reasons:\\n        Immediately acknowledges a widespread pain point (nobody loves email)\\n        \\\"We all\\\" creates a sense of shared experience and community around the core problem\\n        Creates curiosity about how Cora might solve this universal challenge when everyone before them has come up short\\n        The brevity and directness avoids marketing hype and instead encourages potential users to simply try it for themselves\\n        Opens with a problem statement that primes users to be receptive to Cora's solution\\n        Uses \\\"dread\\\" which is a strong emotional word that resonates with many (all?) email users\\n        The simple and conversational tone feels authentic and relatable\\n        Avoids technical language while still identifying the problem that Cora aims to address\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Science you can hear</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nBrain.fm's marketing headline on their /science page is \\\"Science you can hear\\\". clips.</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nDescript's homepage rotates through three marketing headlines, but the headline \\\"If you can edit text, you can make viral clips.\\\" is the most effective in my opinion. Here's why.\\nThe \\\"If you can... you can\\\" structure brilliantly connects a familiar skill that we all have (editing text) to a desirable outcome (creating viral clips). This makes complex video editing and going viral feel accessible.\\n\\\"Viral clips\\\" addresses a creator's aspirations while suggesting Descript can help achieve social media success that they've likely been chasing.\\nThe headline also cleverly implies that Descript makes video editing as simple as text editing, without explicitly stating it.\\nOverall, this headline works by promising to transform a common skill into a desired outcome, making video creation feel approachable while maintaining the aspiration of viral success.\\nOh… and in case you didn't know… there are currently 162 million amateur content creators. That's 162 million people that would love to go viral.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Sites & eCom so easy, Grandma can do it.</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nMuse's marketing headline \\\"Sites & eCom so easy, Grandma can do it.\\\" stands out and certainly stops the scroll.\\nUsing \\\"Grandma\\\" as a proxy for technological inexperience attempts to highlight just how easy Muse it to use. It's important to note that choosing an H1 like this may potentially alienate a subset of people. Muse weighed the pros and cons and decided that the pros won out (and I would agree).\\nThis promise of simplicity for website and ecommerce creation is compelling. There are countless tools in the space and most have their fair share of annoyances and quirks.\\nOverall, Muse's H1 effectively communicates their core value proposition, making complicated website and ecommerce creation accessible to users of all technical skill levels.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Go beyond your mind’s limitations</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nLimitless's headline \\\"Go beyond your mind's limitations\\\" was a scroll-stopper.\\nThe phrase \\\"Go beyond\\\" is an active call to action, encouraging readers to push themselves further. It implies movement and progress, which can be highly motivating.\\nBy referencing \\\"your mind's limitations,\\\" the headline acknowledges that people often feel constrained by their own mental barriers. This recognition of a common human experience can resonate strongly with many individuals.\\nThe headline does a great job of tapping into the widespread desire for self-improvement and personal growth. It suggests that Limitless can help users transcend their current mental state or capabilities.\\nThe headline remains open-ended and applicable to various aspects of one's mental performance, whether it's creativity, problem-solving, or overall memory. This broad appeal likely attract a wide range of users with different goals.\\nBy focusing on overcoming limitations rather than specific skills, the headline avoids pigeonholing the product. It suggests that Limitless can be beneficial regardless of a person's starting point or current areas of struggle.\\nThe use of \\\"your\\\" personalizes the message, which is always a marketing win. This makes it feel more directly relevant to each individual that comes across it. It suggests that Limitless can and will be tailored to each person's unique needs.\\nOverall, this headline is effective because it promises personal transformation and growth in a concise, powerful statement. It addresses a universal human desire to improve and overcome limitations, positioning Limitless as a tool for unlocking one's full potential.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>The journal that reflects with you</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nPearl's headline \\\"The journal that reflects with you\\\" is a marketing headline that works partly due to the use of italics.\\nThe word \\\"reflects\\\" carries a clever double meaning here. It suggests both the act of personal reflection (as one does when journaling) and the idea that the journal is responsive or actually participates with you.\\nBy saying \\\"with you\\\" rather than \\\"for you,\\\" the headline implies partnership and collaboration. It suggests that Pearl isn't just a passive tool but an active participant in the journaling process. The use of italics on \\\"with\\\" really drives this point home here.\\nThe use of \\\"the\\\" rather than \\\"a\\\" to start the headline positions Pearl as the definitive journaling solution. This subtle choice suggests a level of authority in the crowded journaling space.\\nThe headline avoids technical language about AI even though it is implied, instead focusing on the emotional and personal aspect of journaling. This keeps the technology in the background while emphasizing the human experience.\\nOverall, this headline is effective because it positions Pearl not as just another journaling app but as a thoughtful companion in the reflection process. It promises a more interactive and meaningful journaling experience without being overly technical or losing the personal touch that makes journaling special.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>The future of storytelling starts here.</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nIncention's marketing headline \\\"The future of storytelling starts here.\\\" in all caps and bold font really stands out and immediately stops your scroll.\\n\\\"The future\\\" suggests that they're leading a transformation in storytelling rather than just iterating on existing methods.\\n\\\"Starts here\\\" creates immediacy and makes the user potential feel like they're at the beginning of something significant. It invites them to be part of this future.\\nBy using \\\"storytelling\\\", the headline maintains broad appeal while expanding the tool's target market beyond just content creation.\\nFinally, the period adds confidence to the statement, implying certainty about Incention's role in shaping storytelling's future.\\nMic drop.\\nFrom their Twitter/X:\\nOur Manifesto: The future of storytelling starts here.\\nNot with algorithms replacing humans, but with technology empowering creators.\\nNot fear of what AI might do, but excitement for what we can achieve together.\\nNot winner-take-all or most, but positive sum collaboration.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Email for you. Yes, you.</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nButtondown's headline \\\"Email for you. Yes, you.\\\" immediately grabbed my attention and made me stop and question what this truly meant.\\nThe direct messaging of \\\"you\\\" creates an immediate personal connection. The repetition and emphasis with \\\"Yes, you\\\" makes it even more intimate, as if Buttondown is starting a one-on-one conversation with the reader/potential user.\\nThis same addition of \\\"Yes, you\\\" cleverly anticipates and addresses potential skepticism. It's as if Buttondown is saying \\\"Yes, we really did make this for someone like you,\\\" making the reader feel specifically considered and valued.\\nThe simplicity of \\\"Email for you\\\" suggests that Buttondown has stripped away complexity in an often confusing and feature-packed industry of email.\\nNow, I will say that I knew what Buttondown did before stumbling across this headline. I do think it's possibly a bit too vague without the use of a subheading for those that are not already familiar.\\nIs this for newsletters? A Gmail replacement? A subheading would help clear this up so that the H1 is even more powerful.\\nIn Buttondown's words:\\nHistorically, we've called Buttondown a 'newsletter tool' — the h1 before this was 'The best way to start and grow your newsletter.' This was really nice and effective, but I talked with a number of folks who felt a little turned off by that word \\\"newsletter\\\", as if it felt amateurish or insufficiently \\\"haha business\\\" (for lack of a better term) for their use case.\\nSo I started toying around with replacing \\\"newsletter\\\" with \\\"email\\\" as the proper noun that we'd rally around (and email has its own baggage, to be clear — there's a handful of people who sign up thinking that we're, like, a Proton Mail alternative.) And the more I liked \\\"email\\\", the more I hated \\\"email <buzzword>\\\" — email automation, email marketing, email campaigns all felt very corporate and stodgy in a way that betrayed the unique voice I think most of our marketing copy has. Eventually I landed on \\\"email for people like you\\\", which I liked but lacked... a certain punch, if you know what I mean.\\nFinally, I was batting around ideas and landed on the current two-sentence structure, which I think accomplishes a handful of things:\\n1. Tells the user, frankly, nothing about our product or positioning besides \\\"email\\\" (and therefore invites them to learn more)\\n2. Immediately gives us a certain voice and friendliness that is, uh, _missing_ from the Constant Contacts of the world.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Calm your mind. Their core offering is based on Physical AI, which fuses 4D radar and cameras to create high-resolution 3D maps with semantic understanding. They leverage existing sensors on machines and offer modular solutions that scale with the site. Their products aim to improve productivity, safety, and resource efficiency by reducing downtime, avoiding accidents, and eliminating avoidable maintenance.\\n\\nTheir platform includes the following products:\\n- sensmore Site OS: This is presented as the single source of truth for live site operations. It provides a complete live view of operations through a single dashboard with real-time operational intelligence, live insights, customizable zones (speed zones, restricted zones, material zones, points of interest), and material flow information. It allows for simplified operational management by directly updating changes on deployed Machine Assists and optimizing dispatching based on data insights.\\n- sensmore Machine Assist: This product provides drivers with real-time situational awareness and collision warnings for people, machinery, and static objects. It is built to perform in harsh conditions using advanced AI and 4D radar technology for reliable collision detection in all weather. It uses Physical AI to detect and classify collisions and RTK GNSS Localization for live centimeter accuracy in vehicle positioning. It features a lean hardware kit that can be equipped quickly and is GDPR compliant. It can operate in a Tablet-Only Mode and utilizes Beacons.\\n- sensmore Eye: This offers vision-based quality control for smarter operations. It monitors crusher levels to maximize throughput and prevent blockages, detects oversized boulders before they cause blockages, and assesses material volume and quality in real time. It uses AI-Powered Visual Monitoring of machinery like crushers, conveyor belts, and stockpiles and integrates seamlessly with Site OS for real-time visual data access from any device.\\n- sensmore Live Mapping: This provides live mapping as a site's digital twin, which is always up to date and accurate. It offers unprecedented visibility with real-time updates to the digital terrain model, allowing users to track changes, plan operations, and maintain complete situational awareness. It is modular, integrates seamlessly, and provides analytics. It runs on the Machine Assist hardware and leverages existing sensors. It uses multi-sensor 3D mapping by fusing 4D radar and cameras and stores data securely in the cloud for real-time accessibility.\\n- sensmore Loader Automation: This provides fully automated load and carry capabilities for material handling tasks in any condition with zero-shot autonomy. It is powered by sensmore's end-to-end learning AI and VLAM models, enabling loaders to adapt instantly to new challenges without prior training. It features human-centric control, allowing interaction with machinery using simple language commands, unlimited adaptability to dynamic environments, zero-shot autonomy for executing new tasks instantly, and seamless integration into operational workflows.\\n\\nsensmore positions itself as a pioneer in developing embodied AI and VLAM for heavy machinery, aiming to go beyond mere automation by infusing human-like intelligence into machines. \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst buffer = 0; // 4rem buffer instead of 1rem\\\\n67: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tmaxScrollDistance += buffer;\\\\n68: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}\\\\n69: \\\\n70: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif From collision warnings to real-time site intelligence, you get more out of every machine and every minute.</p>\\\\n\\\\n<h3>One platform. Set speed zones, track material flows, and dispatch smarter based on what’s actually happening.</p>\\\\n\\\\n  <h4>Prevent incidents + cut downtime</h4>\\\\n  <p><strong>Machine Assist</strong> keeps your operators safe with real-time object, person, and vehicle alerts. Built on 4D radar and onboard AI that works when cameras can’t.</p>\\\\n\\\\n  <h4>Run smarter load and carry</h4>\\\\n  <p><strong>Loader Automation</strong> powers your loaders with end-to-end autonomy—able to detect, respond, and handle new routes instantly, no retraining needed.</p>\\\\n\\\\n  <h4>Monitor materials without stopping flow</h4>\\\\n  <p><strong>Eye</strong> measures crusher levels, detects oversize rocks early, and keeps quality high with live vision data—all integrated into Site OS.</p>\\\\n\\\\n  <h4>Create your site’s digital twin</h4>\\\\n  <p><strong>Live Mapping</strong> offers continual 3D mapping based on 4D radar and cameras, updating terrain and infrastructure as they shift.</p>\\\\n</section>\\\\n\\\\n<h3>Built tough. Rendering:**\n\n   - The `<Testimonials>` component is imported and used directly within the `+page.svelte` file.\n   - It's placed after the `<Summary>` component.\n\n**2. Props:**\n\n   - The `<Testimonials>` component takes a `testimonials` prop.\n   - The `testimonials` prop is an array of `Testimonial` objects.\n   - The `Testimonial` type is defined within the `./src/lib/components/layout/Testimonials.svelte` file.\n\n**3. Structure of the Testimonial Component:**\n\n   - The component uses a `section` element with a `wrapperRef` to calculate the scroll position.\n   - It uses a `div` with `carouselRef` to hold the testimonials.\n   - The component uses a `div` to hold the testimonials.\n   - Inside the `div`, it iterates over the `testimonials` array using an `#each` block.\n   - Each testimonial is rendered within an `article` element.\n   - Each `article` contains:\n     - An image of the person.\n     - A quote (`q` tag).\n     - A citation (`cite` tag) with the author's name, position, and company.\n   - It also includes pagination indicators.\n\n"}]},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"tool-call","toolCallId":"call_PXXKEA4me0xE4F9oy1e746GH","toolName":"view_file","args":{"path":"./src/lib/components/layout/Testimonials.svelte"}}],"id":"msg-eJs3mCaLYvu541KNEW8bYHcE"},{"role":"tool","id":"msg-zmmF7loYWlXyfL1zYHqWNay2","content":[{"type":"tool-result","toolCallId":"call_PXXKEA4me0xE4F9oy1e746GH","toolName":"view_file","result":"1: \t\t\tconst viewportWidth = window.innerWidth;\n45: \t\t\t// Get the width of the last card\n46: \t\t\tconst lastCard = cards[cards.length - 1];\n47: \t\t\tconst lastCardWidth = lastCard.offsetWidth;\n48: \n49: \t\t\t// Get computed styles to account for gaps and padding\n50: \t\t\tconst style = getComputedStyle(carouselRef);\n51: \t\t\tconst gapStr = style.gap || style.columnGap || \"0px\";\n52: \t\t\tconst gapValue = parseInt(gapStr, 10) || 0;\n53: \n54: \t\t\t// To ensure the last card is fully visible at the end of the scroll,\n55: \t\t\t// we need to make sure the last card's right edge aligns with the viewport's right edge\n56: \t\t\t// This means the maximum distance we need to translate is:\n57: \t\t\t// (total carousel width - viewport width)\n58: \t\t\t// If this value is negative or zero, no scrolling is needed\n59: \t\t\tmaxScrollDistance = Math.max(0, carouselWidth - viewportWidth);\n60: \n61: \t\t\t// Ensure we can see the last card fully\n62: \t\t\t// This extra adjustment ensures the last card is properly positioned at the end of the scroll\n63: \t\t\tif (maxScrollDistance > 0) {\n64: \t\t\t\t// Add a larger buffer for more breathing room at the right edge\n65: \t\t\t\t// This accounts for any padding or margin that might affect positioning\n66: \t\t\t\tconst buffer = 0; // 4rem buffer instead of 1rem\n67: \t\t\t\tmaxScrollDistance += buffer;\n68: \t\t\t}\n69: \n70: \t\t\tif (maxScrollDistance <= 0) {\n71: \t\t\t\tconsole.info(\"Content fits in viewport, no scrolling needed\");\n72: \t\t\t}\n73: \t\t};\n74: \n75: \t\t// Track vertical scroll position and convert to horizontal scroll\n76: \t\tlet ticking = false;\n77: \t\tconst handleScroll = () => {\n78: \t\t\tif (ticking) return;\n79: \t\t\tticking = true;\n80: \n81: \t\t\trequestAnimationFrame(() => {\n82: \t\t\t\tif (!wrapperRef) return;\n83: \n84: \t\t\t\tconst rect = wrapperRef.getBoundingClientRect();\n85: \t\t\t\tconst {\n91: \t\t\t\t\tprogress = Math.min(Math.abs(rect.top) / (sectionHeight - viewportHeight), 1);\n92: \t\t\t\t}\n93: \n94: \t\t\t\tscrollProgress = progress;\n95: \t\t\t\tcurrent = \t\t\t\tupdateDimensions();\n106: \t\t\t\thandleScroll();\n107: \t\t\t}, 100);\n108: \t\t};\n109: \n110: \t\t// Initialize and set up listeners\n111: \t\tupdateDimensions();\n112: From collision warnings to real-time site intelligence, you get more out of every machine and every minute.</p>\n\n<h3>One platform. Fewer problems.</h3>\n<p>We turn machine data into live operational insights and automated actions—all in environments where GPS fails and visibility drops. Because your site doesn’t get days off for weather.</p>\n\n<h3>What you can do with sensmore:</h3>\n\n<section>\n  <h4>See everything on site—in real time</h4>\n  <p><strong>Site OS</strong> gives you a full view of your operation from one smart dashboard. Set speed zones, track material flows, and dispatch smarter based on what’s actually happening.</p>\n\n  <h4>Prevent incidents + cut downtime</h4>\n  <p><strong>Machine Assist</strong> keeps your operators safe with real-time object, person, and vehicle alerts. Built on 4D radar and onboard AI that works when cameras can’t.</p>\n\n  <h4>Run smarter load and carry</h4>\n  <p><strong>Loader Automation</strong> powers your loaders with end-to-end autonomy—able to detect, respond, and handle new routes instantly, no retraining needed.</p>\n\n  <h4>Monitor materials without stopping flow</h4>\n  <p><strong>Eye</strong> measures crusher levels, detects oversize rocks early, and keeps quality high with live vision data—all integrated into Site OS.</p>\n\n  <h4>Create your site’s digital twin</h4>\n  <p><strong>Live Mapping</strong> offers continual 3D mapping based on 4D radar and cameras, updating terrain and infrastructure as they shift.</p>\n</section>\n\n<h3>Built tough. Ready anywhere.</h3>\n<ul>\n  <li>Works in harsh and GNSS-denied environments</li>\n  <li>Runs on existing sensors and lean retrofit hardware</li>\n  <li>GDPR-compliant, human-friendly, and safety-beneficial</li>\n  <li>Scales modularly across operations and fleet size</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Trusted by hardworking operators</h3>\n\n<blockquote>\n  “Planning and dispatch that used to take me 3 hours a day now takes 30 minutes because of the live insights from Site OS. That means the beginning of the sentence has a capital letter and rest is capitalized normally.\\n  - ✅ Good: \\\"The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog\\\"\\n  - ✅ Good: \\\"Peter Parker is a superhero in the Marvel Universe\\\"\\n  - ❌ Bad: \\\"The Quick Brown Fox Jumps Over The Lazy Dog\\\"\\n  - ❌ Bad: \\\"the quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog\\\"\\n  - ❌ Bad: \\\"the quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog\\\"\\n- Keep copy concise and direct.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n- Use the `writeCopy` tool for ALL copywriting tasks and text changes.\\n\\n## Image guidelines\\n- Generate new images using the `generateImages` tool whenever adding images.\\n- NEVER reuse existing images from the codebase.\\n- Only use aspect ratios: `1:1`, `9:16`, `16:9`, `3:4`, or `4:3`.\\n\\n## HTML and scripts\\n- Add user-provided scripts directly into the `app.html` file.\\n- NEVER pass HTML entities into JavaScript strings; use them only in HTML if necessary.\\n\\n## Svelte props declaration\\nWhen updating props, make 100% sure the format is correct. no missing commas, quotes, brackets, or any other syntax errors should be present. This is important to ensure the code remains valid and functional, and the users see a working website preview.\\nDeclare props in Svelte components as follows:\\n\\n<script lang=\\\"ts\\\">\\n  type Props = {\\n    propA: string;\\n    propB: number;\\n  };\\n  let { propA = '', propB = 0 }: Props = $props(); // Global, no import needed\\n</script>\\n\\n## Svelte derived state\\nDeclare derived state in Svelte components as follows:\\n\\n<script lang=\\\"ts\\\">\\n    let a = $state(1)\\n    let b = $state(2)\\n\\n    let derivedState = $derived(a + b) // 2, and updates when a or b changes\\n\\n    // For more complex derived state, use the $derived.vby function with a callback\\n    let complexDerivedState = $derived.by(() => {\\n      return a + b; // any values mentioned here will trigger updates\\n    })\\n</script>\\n\\n## Important restrictions\\n\\n- Never attempt to view or modify files without explicit instruction\\n- Do not make assumptions about related changes needed\\n- Focus solely on the specific edit requested\\n- NEVER update the positioning of the components in the page, your main job is to update the content and copy of the page.\\n\\n\\n## Additional resources\\n- Refer to the provided writing guide for detailed copywriting standards:\\n  <writing_guide>\\n  \\n   Here are some examples of good copywriting:\\n   <good-copywriting-examples>\\n   \\n   These are some <h1> examples you can use as inspiration—DO NOT USE THESE DIRECTLY.\\n   <h1-examples>\\n   - Time is money. It works well for these reasons:\\n        Immediately acknowledges a widespread pain point (nobody loves email)\\n        \\\"We all\\\" creates a sense of shared experience and community around the core problem\\n        Creates curiosity about how Cora might solve this universal challenge when everyone before them has come up short\\n        The brevity and directness avoids marketing hype and instead encourages potential users to simply try it for themselves\\n        Opens with a problem statement that primes users to be receptive to Cora's solution\\n        Uses \\\"dread\\\" which is a strong emotional word that resonates with many (all?) email users\\n        The simple and conversational tone feels authentic and relatable\\n        Avoids technical language while still identifying the problem that Cora aims to address\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Science you can hear</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nBrain.fm's marketing headline on their /science page is \\\"Science you can hear\\\".
